unnormalised: Someone asked me how much groceries typically cost in a month in India. Well, it really depends! For a small family (say, 2 adults and 1 child) in a metro city like Mumbai or Delhi, you're probably looking at Rs. 8000-Rs. 12000 per month. That's if you're buying from local markets and D-Mart. If you prefer shopping at places like Nature's Basket, add another Rs. 3000-Rs. 5000 easily.
normalised: Someone asked me how much groceries typically cost in a month in India. Well, it really depends! For a small family (say, two adults and one child) in a metro city like Mumbai or Delhi, you're probably looking at rupee eight thousand to rupee twelve thousand per month. That's if you're buying from local markets and D-Mart. If you prefer shopping at places like Nature's Basket, add another rupee three thousand to rupee five thousand easily.

unnormalised: The biggest chunk of that cost comes from staples: rice (maybe 25 kg a month), wheat flour (around 10 kg), dals (various kinds, totalling maybe 5 kg), and cooking oil (3-4 liters). Veggies fluctuate wildly in price, especially during monsoon! Sometimes tomatoes are Rs. 20/kg, sometimes they're Rs. 100/kg. Fruits also add up, maybe Rs. 2000-Rs. 3000 a month if you're buying regularly. And don’t forget milk and eggs, which could set you back another Rs. 1500.
normalised: The biggest chunk of that cost comes from staples: rice (maybe twenty five kilogram a month), wheat flour (around ten kilogram), dals (various kinds, totalling maybe five kilogram), and cooking oil (three to four liters). Veggies fluctuate wildly in price, especially during monsoon! Sometimes tomatoes are rupee twenty per kilogram, sometimes they're rupee one hundred per kilogram. Fruits also add up, maybe rupee two thousand to rupee three thousand a month if you're buying regularly. And don’t forget milk and eggs, which could set you back another rupee one thousand five hundred.

unnormalised: Then there are the miscellaneous items: spices, tea/coffee, sugar, snacks, etc., which can easily add another Rs. 2000. And of course, occasional treats from the bakery or a quick trip to the supermarket for chips and biscuits - budget at least Rs. 1000 for that. So, realistically, plan for a budget of around 10k-15k, and you'll be on the safer side.
